div.p:
Pay no regard to Imperial critics, a moral
that is not prominent scarcely deserves the title -
it's enough for you that it is clothd clothed in a story
which you have compelled the reader to go through.
I agree with you that the titles mottos should be altered
or omitted; but not in substituting Miss for
Maria - however, if authors allow themselves to
be turned out by aristocrats or silly people of fashion of the good common sense road
I suppose booksellers must stay with them.
You need not transcribe to the erata errata already
sent, it's perfectly intelligible, only give me
any more you have discovered, & your altered
preface, for we must go to press very soon
indeed. Give my respect to your corrector D.r Beaufort.

There was a mistake, yr. copy of Darwin's Life
with from the author was not intended for Mr. E.

whose candour I admire in speaking of the book,
& Mrs. S. shall know it. What is beyond rendering good for evil?
Modern Sketches is a title I believe already occupied,
I think I once mentioned Tales for people of fashion
able people, or fashionable people, or Tales for
high life, but your inventive brain will supply
a better than can be furnished by any one else,
especially as you but know the subjects.
We should have a longer tale than Griselda, to
accompany it & make a volume.

In your late letters you have overpowered me with kindness.
If I had a title & a fortune, neither of which I wish for
on my own account, & were thirty years younger, and
you liked me as much as I admire you, the ladies
in yr
your house would decide the consequence

Thank your father for his ready compliance with my request
respecting the Speaker, & the ladies for thinking of yr. your affectaffectionate hmblehumble J. Johnson

Suard has lately pubd. published at Paris Melanges de Litterature
in 3 Vol. 8o., in the work he has a letter from Ireland
in which he gives the Substance of parts of Castle RacCastle Rackrent but differs from many thieves for he acknowledges
the source of his information & pays a tribute of
respect to the Author. I hardly think that you
need trouble yourself about sending Pictet, information about
anything that is published, he has not doubt plandplanned sources of intelligence
